posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
Right now, my team uses wpilib’s arcade drive with a very top heavy tank robot. We apply a two different multipliers for throttle and turning, and have a slew rate for throttle to control acceleration. We’ve running this for a while and found that our turning felt very unintuivative. Also, we’ve been tipping whenever we get hit by other robots. I was wondering a few things

How I can implement cheesy or curvature drive without tipping while turning at high speeds.

Or modify our turn scaling for arcade to turn to feel more consistent while prohibiting fast turns at high speeds.

I will take any suggestions. This is our current code. I think the multiplier may have something to do with unconsistent turning, but I’m not sure.

Edit: There are no mechanical changes we can make to the arm/end effector to significantly relocate weight. Testing controller inputs vs real life results and applying variable limits / curves is our only tool.

posts.name: dmorewood
posts.cooked: I can’t code for my life - so I can’t help your original question. But if you have any weight, buy scraps of steel and bolt it to your frame (on the OPPOSITE side from your battery cause that’s the heaviest thing on your belly I’m assuming). 254 has done this pretty successfully, their robot makes defense bounce off like its nothing

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
Also not the answer you’re looking for, but as much as I’d like software fix all my mechanical problems, if the robot is top heavy you need fix it mechanically to get the performance your looking for.

My advice is to work with your mechanical people to remove weight up high ( remove aesthetic or limited use mechanisms, use thinner or lighter materials etc.), and add weight down low. If you have weight budget left in your bumpers that could be a great place to both lower CG and move it around front to back or side to side.

i couldn’t help you with coding or anything but my team has (i think it’s 25 lbs) weight at the bottom of our robot so that it lowers our center of gravity. this resulted in our balance point being around 80 degrees, we’ve only tipped 2 times in official matches (both were related to being stuck on the corner of a charge station) but i would also say remove some higher weight as well, it’ll help

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Right now, we are 124.5 lbs heavy, so we can’t add anymore weight to the bottom. We’ve already have a 25 lbs dumbell attached to the front of our robot (sorry for the vague post). But thank you so much for all your advices, I will tell my mechanical team if we can do anything about the weight of the robot.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Presumably, you are preparing for competing at Houston Championship.

Make sure your ballast is securely attached to a sufficiently strong part of your chassis. I was part of the inspection team at the Space City and FiT District Championship events. We were given the edict “only metal fasteners” by the Chief LRIs so any ballast attached with zip ties or Velcro is an instant fail. We worked with one team to attach their ballast using steel zip ties and they failed in the next match. Another had their ballast bolted onto a piece of steel with 3/8" or 1/2" bolts but after a number of matches, the bolts turned the holes in the steel mounting plate into large ovals and the ballast popped out.

Best of luck at Houston Championship!

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked:
I have a few things you can try:

Have to experimented with adjusting ramp rates in your Spark Max drivetrain?  It may help reduce jerky drive movements which can cause accelerations resulting in tipping.

Have you considered closed loop velocity control on your drive rather than arcade drive’s standard set() to joystick mapping?

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Thank you very much! We are indeed preparing for Houston, so we’re very short on time. I’ll be sure to warn my mechanical team if we are decide to add ballast.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Tipping happens because forces in the drivetrain act on a point not in line with the center of mass. In turn, this causes a torque that rotates the whole robot, eventually to the point where the system is unstable and the robot falls.

Your only two options are moving the center of mass, or reducing forces.

Software can help, as long as it does one of those two things. However, there is no silver bullet for getting around the laws of physics.

You always need to limit translational acceleration to reduce the tip-inducing forces. Rotation while still can be ok, but rotation while translating will also be tip inducing.

You can try to get more clever about how to limit acceleration, but there will always be diminishing returns at a point.

posts.name: Victor
posts.cooked:
Or modify our turn scaling for arcade to turn to feel more consistent while prohibiting fast turns at high speeds.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
We haven’t experienced adjusting ramp rates because we used slew rates, so we could manually adjust acceleration and deceleration separately. I don’t know if there’s a big difference between the limiting ramp of the controller inputs or voltage.

I have considered use closed loop velocity control, but haven’t got around to prototyping due to time. I heard 971 has great code for that but I can’t read C++

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Thank you for the explanation, it was very clear. I will see if we can make an adjustments to the center of mass.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Oooo thank you for your code and comments, I will try it in shop to see how our driver likes it.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Stainless steel hose clamps with bands 3/8" or 1/2" wide have been accepted at all events I volunteered at this season and last season. I have not heard of them failing with the type of weight you are using. Use two so the barbell doesn’t move around. Had to help a team find a replacement for their main breaker because their ballast moved and broke it in half.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
gerthworm:

Your only two options are moving the center of mass, or reducing forces.

Another option mechanically is to get that counterbalance weight spread out to the max. This will impact the rotational inertia of the robot, which may make it turn ever so slightly differently, but a greater moment of inertia should help with some tippyness

OP, biggest thing is get some mass from up high to down low. You can’t fix everything in code, mechanical needs to perhaps accept a lot of responsibility here.

gerthworm:

You always need to limit translational acceleration to reduce the tip-inducing forces. Rotation while still can be ok, but rotation while translating will also be tip inducing.

An extreme example:

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
As @Skyehawk noted, where you put the ballast can be very important. Experiment to find the best location. Most Everybots last season had the ballast in the back. This year, most were in the middle or offset to the rear, possibly due to existing components.

Best of luck in Houston. See if you can get out to visit Johnson Space Center as well as getting some crayfish.
Change to a velocity PID controller drive system and use acceleration limits including for rotational acceleration and you can perfectly limit it to prevent tipping it just takes some tuning
